january.quote: At dawn, when you have trouble getting out of bed, tell yourself: 'I have to go to work—as a human being. What do I have to complain of, if I'm going to do what I was born for—the things I was brought into the world to do?'
First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.
No man is free who is not master of himself.

If you accomplish something good with hard work, the labor passes quickly, but the good endures; if you do something shameful in pursuit of pleasure, the pleasure passes quickly, but the shame endures.
Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.
Waste no more time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.

The chief task in life is simply this: to identify and separate matters so that I can say clearly to myself which are externals not under my control, and which have to do with the choices I actually control.
We are more often frightened than hurt; and we suffer more in imagination than in reality.
If you would be a reader, read; if a writer, write.
Make yourself hard against indulgence and endurance becomes easy.
You have power over your mind—not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
If you are pained by any external thing, it is not this thing that disturbs you, but your own judgment about it. And it is in your power to wipe out this judgment now.
People are not disturbed by things, but by the views they take of them.
Let us train ourselves to desire only that which is necessary.
It is the power of the mind to be unconquerable.
If it is endurable, then endure it. Stop complaining.
Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it.
Every habit and capability is confirmed and grows in its corresponding actions, walking by walking, and running by running.
We should every night call ourselves to an account: What infirmity have I mastered today? What passions opposed? What temptation resisted? What virtue acquired?
The mind that is anxious about future events is miserable.
How long are you going to wait before you demand the best for yourself?
Practice yourself, for heaven's sake, in little things; and thence proceed to greater.
A gem cannot be polished without friction, nor a man perfected without trials.
Take a good hard look at people's ruling principle, especially of the wise, what they run away from and what they seek out.
The soul becomes dyed with the color of its thoughts.
It is not the man who has too little that is poor, but the one who hankers after more.
Demand not that events should happen as you wish; but wish them to happen as they do happen, and you will go on well.
The best revenge is to be unlike him who performed the injury.
Confine yourself to the present.

If anyone tells you that a certain person speaks ill of you, do not make excuses about what is said of you but answer, 'He was ignorant of my other faults, else he would not have mentioned these alone.'
Associate with people who are likely to improve you.

february.quote: What is the fruit of these teachings? Only the most beautiful and proper harvest of the truly educated—tranquility, fearlessness, and freedom.
Wherever there is a human being, there is an opportunity for kindness.
We should meet opposition and find out that it yields and gives way before resolution.

Kindness is invincible, but only when it's sincere, with no hypocrisy or faking. For what can even the most malicious person do if you keep showing kindness and, if given the chance, you gently point out where they went wrong?
The person who does wrong, does wrong to themselves. The unjust person is unjust to themselves—making themselves evil.
Human beings are made for each other; so either teach them better or endure them.
The wrongdoer is often the person who does nothing. A person should not be too inactive, nor too shameless.
It is not enough to acquire wisdom; it must be used.
Don't return injustice with injustice, or wrong with wrong to any person, regardless of what you may have suffered from them.
What does it mean to live? To be active for the common good, to exercise your rational faculty, to refuse to believe the evidence of the senses.
The person who has practiced philosophy as a cure for the self becomes great of soul, filled with confidence, invincible—and greater as you draw near.
A person who doesn't know what the universe is doesn't know where they are. A person who doesn't know their purpose in life doesn't know who they are or what the universe is.
If someone is able to show me that what I think or do is not right, I will happily change, for I seek the truth, by which no one was ever truly harmed.
I cannot escape my kinship with all human beings, nor can I be angry with my relative or hate them. We are made for cooperation.
Receive without pride, let go without attachment.
What is the fruit of your doctrines? Harmony, freedom, tranquility.
Our plans miscarry because they have no aim. When a man does not know what harbor he is making for, no wind is the right wind.
What does not benefit the hive does not benefit the bee.
Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together, but do so with all your heart.
How much more harmful are the consequences of anger and grief than the circumstances that aroused them in us.
If you really do want to become good, first recognize that you are bad.
We are born for cooperation, like feet, like hands, like eyelids, like the rows of upper and lower teeth. To work against one another is therefore contrary to nature.
Keep yourself simple, good, pure, serious, free from affectation, a friend of justice, a worshiper of the gods, kind, affectionate, strenuous in all proper acts.

When force of circumstance upsets your equanimity, lose no time in recovering your self-control, and do not remain out of tune longer than you can help. Habitual recurrence to the harmony will increase your mastery of it.
Don't be ashamed of needing help. You have a duty to fulfill just like a soldier on the wall of battle. So what if you are injured and can't climb up without another soldier's help?
We have two ears and one mouth so that we can listen twice as much as we speak.
No man can live happily who regards himself alone, who turns everything to his own advantage. You must live for another if you wish to live for yourself.
The wise man will not take part in politics except in an emergency.

march.quote: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
It is difficulties that show what men are.
Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
Be like the promontory against which the waves continually break; but it stands firm and tames the fury of the water around it.
The greater the difficulty, the more glory in surmounting it. Skillful pilots gain their reputation from storms and tempests.
Fire is the test of gold; adversity, of strong men.
Nothing happens to any man which he is not formed by nature to bear.
Don't avoid hardship, for this is what nature demands; embrace it as an athlete would embrace their training.
Calamity is virtue's opportunity.
Choose not to be harmed—and you won't feel harmed. Don't feel harmed—and you haven't been.
The trials you endure and overcome will be the very things to strengthen and mature you.
No man is crushed by misfortune unless he has first been deceived by prosperity.
A man's worth is no greater than the worth of his ambitions.
The man who has anticipated the coming of troubles takes away their power when they arrive.
He who has made a fair compact with poverty is rich.
Nothing bad can happen to a good man, whether in life or after death.
Sometimes even to live is an act of courage.
Difficulty is what wakes up the genius.
When you are discouraged, do not look around for someone to support you; support yourself.
Hardship strengthens the mind and gives endurance, just as training strengthens the body.
Circumstances do not make the man, they reveal him.
The brave man is not he who does not feel afraid, but he who conquers that fear.
If thou art pained by any external thing, it is not this thing that disturbs thee, but thy own judgment about it.
No good man ever grew rich suddenly.
Remember that to change your mind and to follow him who sets you right is to be none the less free than you were before.
Misfortune nobly borne is good fortune.
He who fears he will suffer, already suffers from his fear.
It's not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
Fortune falls heavily on those for whom she is unexpected; he for whom she has always been precarious easily endures her.
External things are not the problem. It's your assessment of them. Which you can erase right now.
All cruelty springs from weakness.

april.quote: Accept whatever comes to you woven in the pattern of your destiny, for what could more aptly fit your needs?
Follow where reason leads.
Everything is in a state of change, and you yourself are in continuous flux and in some respects destruction, and the whole universe too.
Living in accordance with nature means understanding that some things are in our control and others are not.
The universe is transformation; life is opinion.
Nothing according to nature is evil.
Remember that all is opinion.
Nature does not demand what she has not given us the ability to endure.
Observe constantly that all things take place by change, and accustom yourself to consider that the nature of the Universe loves nothing so much as to change.
God has entrusted me with myself. No one is more interested than I in not harming myself.
Look at all existing things: they are already in dissolution and in change.
Everything harmonizes with me which is harmonious to you, O Universe. Nothing for me is too early or too late which is in due time for you.
If you wish to live a life free from sorrow, think of what is going to happen as if it had already happened.
Nature has made us adaptable, she has made us capable of enduring everything.
Everything existing in the universe is the fruit of chance and necessity.
See things for what they are.
The rational soul wanders around the whole world and through the surrounding void, and gazes into infinite time, and considers the periodic destructions and rebirths of the universe.
Nothing is by nature evil.
Nature does not require us to do things that are impossible.
All things are woven together and the common bond is sacred.
In the life of a man, his time is but a moment, his being an incessant flux.
All is ephemeral—fame and the famous as well.
Be satisfied with what nature has given you.
The willing are led by fate, the reluctant dragged.
Everything that happens, happens as it should.
The universe is a single living being, embracing all living beings within it.
True good is in the mind and nothing else.
There is no evil in the world except that which you make so by thinking.
Nature gave us one tongue and two ears so we could hear twice as much as we speak.
What is bad luck? Opinion. What is conflict? Opinion. What is lamentation, grief, and depression? All these are opinions.

may.quote: Virtue is nothing else than right reason.
If it is not right, do not do it. If it is not true, do not say it.
The chief good is the exercise of virtue in a perfect life.
If you are to live in accord with nature, you must first know your own nature.
Courage is knowing what not to fear.
Nothing is good except what is honourable, and nothing is bad except what is shameful.
Character is destiny.
Justice is the crowning glory of the virtues.
Know first who you are, and then adorn yourself accordingly.
True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.
How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does or thinks.
Wisdom without virtue is a dangerous thing.
The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
It is the mark of a good man not only to know how to do right but to be willing to submit to wrong.
What is it you want? To live long? But being old and being young have the same virtue.
Our life is what our thoughts make it.
The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.
Temperance is moderation in all things healthy, total abstinence from all things harmful.
He who is brave is free.
A man's life is what his thoughts make of it.
The shortest and surest way to live with honor in the world is to be in reality what we would appear to be.
Virtue alone affords everlasting and peace-giving joy.
Let your watchword be silence, or speak something more valuable than silence.
The measure of a man is what he does with power.
may.attribution: Attributed to Plato, cited by Marcus Aurelius - Meditations 11.18

may.quote: Do everything as if someone were watching.
Reflect often on the rapidity with which all existing things pass away.
The wise man sees more from the bottom of a well than the fool from a mountain top.
Where is the good? In the will. Where is the evil? In the will.
Let all your efforts be directed to something, let it keep that end in view.
Nature has given us the seeds of knowledge, not knowledge itself.
Very little is needed for everything to be upset and ruined, only a slight change in circumstances.

june.quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
He who studies with a philosopher should take away with him some one good thing every day.
Nowhere can man find a quieter or more untroubled retreat than in his own soul.
The wise man is neither injured by poverty nor by pain nor by the other hardships of life.
Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them.
The mind should be trained to desire what the situation demands.
Very little is needed to make a happy life; it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking.
While we wait for life, life passes.
june.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 9.1

june.quote: Look back over the past, with its changing empires that rose and fell, and you can foresee the future too.
To be a philosopher is not merely to have subtle thoughts, but so to love wisdom as to live according to its dictates.
Philosophy is not about studying books, but about correcting our lives.
True wisdom gives the only true happiness.
Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact. Everything we see is a perspective, not the truth.
If virtue promises happiness, prosperity and peace, then progress in virtue is progress in each of these.
The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
Wisdom does not show itself so much in precept as in life—in a firmness of mind and a mastery of appetite.
Of what use is a philosopher who doesn't hurt anybody's feelings?
The acquisition of wealth is ignoble, its exercise glorious, and its loss infamous.
A person who does not know what the universe is does not know who he is.
No man was ever wise by chance.
The philosopher's school is a surgery: pain, not pleasure, you should have felt therein.
Show me a man who isn't a slave; one is a slave to lust, another to greed, another to ambition, and all men are slaves to fear.
The mind that is free from passions is a citadel; man has no stronger fortress in which to seek shelter.
Be careful to leave your sons well instructed rather than rich, for the hopes of the instructed are better than the wealth of the ignorant.
The willing, Destiny guides them; the unwilling, Destiny drags them.
It's not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste much of it.
june.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 1.3

june.quote: Look within. Within is the fountain of good, and it will ever bubble up, if thou wilt ever dig.
What then makes a man free from hindrance and self-governing? It is property, you will say. No, property does not do that.
The greatest wealth is a poverty of desires.
How ridiculous and how strange to be surprised at anything which happens in life.

july.quote: The only real prison is fear, and the only real freedom is freedom from fear.
Freedom is the only worthy goal in life. It is won by disregarding things that lie beyond our control.
The primary indication of a well-ordered mind is a man's ability to remain in one place and linger in his own company.
He is a wise man who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.
The man who is not enslaved is the man who can use things at his pleasure.
Is freedom anything else than the right to live as we wish? Nothing else.
The wise man is self-sufficient. Not that he wishes to be without friends, but that he is able to be.
Think of the life you have lived until now as over and, as a dead man, see what's left as a bonus.
Who then is free? The wise man who can command himself.
Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
A man is as unhappy as he has convinced himself he is.
The tranquility that comes when you stop caring what they say. Or think, or do. Only what you do.
Freedom is secured not by the fulfilling of men's desires, but by the removal of desire.
A man who suffers before it is necessary suffers more than is necessary.
Today I escaped from anxiety. Or no, I discarded it, because it was within me, in my own perceptions—not outside.
It is impossible for a man to learn what he thinks he already knows.
Set aside a certain number of days during which you shall be content with the scantiest and cheapest fare.
He who fears death will never do anything worthy of a man who is alive.
For what prevents us from saying that the happy life is to have a mind that is free, lofty, fearless and steadfast.
The man who regards all things as equally alien to himself is happy.
What ought one to say then as each hardship comes? I was practicing for this, I was training for this.
If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid.
Men are disturbed not by the things which happen, but by the opinions about the things.
All slavery is bitter, even voluntary slavery.
The first rule is to keep an untroubled spirit. The second is to look things in the face and know them for what they are.
Not being able to govern events, I govern myself.
The chief good is a mind that subjects all things to itself and is itself subject to nothing.
If you seek tranquility, do less. Or more accurately, do what's essential.
Don't be concerned with other people's impressions of you. Think only about how you spend your own time.
If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable.
The greatest obstacle to living is expectancy, which hangs upon tomorrow and loses today.
july.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 9.1

august.quote: No great thing is created suddenly, any more than a bunch of grapes or a fig.
Time discovers truth.
First learn the meaning of what you say, and then speak.
Life is long if you know how to use it.
august.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 2.1

august.quote: The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.
Every habit and capability is confirmed and grows in its corresponding actions.
The best answer to anger is silence.
Fortune falls heavily on those for whom she is unexpected. The one always on the lookout easily endures.
Anything in any way beautiful derives its beauty from itself and asks nothing beyond itself. Praise is no part of it.
Don't let your imagination be crushed by life as a whole. Don't try to picture everything bad that could possibly happen.
The memory of everything is very soon overwhelmed in time.
True happiness consists in not departing from nature and in molding our conduct according to her laws and model.
Why should we suffer in imagination more than in reality?
No man is more unhappy than he who never faces adversity, for he is not permitted to prove himself.
How long will you put off what you are capable of doing just to continue what you are comfortable doing?
Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.
Do not seek to bring things to pass in accordance with your wishes, but wish for them as they are, and you will find peace.
The universe is change; our life is what our thoughts make it.
Nothing great comes into being all at once; even a cluster of grapes requires several seasons.
Pursue the good, but don't be overhasty or rash in your pursuit.
A wise man will not rejoice in prosperity nor will he be depressed by adversity.
Look at how far you've come, not at what still remains to be done.
What man can you show me who places any value on his time, who reckons the worth of each day, who understands that he is dying daily?
august.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 8.5

august.quote: Keep in mind how fast things pass by and are gone—those that are now, and those to come.
A consciousness of wrongdoing is the first step to salvation.
Endure, and keep yourself for better days.
The trials which are applied to a brave man are like the athlete's training.
Wait for the right moment: it will not be late but will come.
In a moment the ashes are made, but the forest is a long time growing.
august.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 10.1

august.quote: Bear in mind that the measure of a man is the worth of the things he cares about.
He who suffers before it is necessary, suffers more than is necessary.

september.quote: The greatest thing in the world is to know how to belong to oneself.
While we are postponing, life speeds by.
Life, if well lived, is long enough.
september.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 1.3

september.quote: It is not death that a man should fear, but rather he should fear never beginning to live.
If a man knows not what harbor he is making for, no wind is the right wind.
You should not consider your own individual life, but the whole.
I begin to be a disciple when my whole focus is on what I am to do and what is to become of me.
Let each man exercise the art he knows.
Put from you the belief that 'I have been wronged,' and with it will go the feeling. Reject your sense of injury, and the injury itself disappears.
We should always allow some time to elapse, for time discloses the truth.
Act with purpose, be resolute, and know the principles by which to live.
Consider that you are dead and have completed your life up to the present moment; and live according to nature in the time that remains.
Not to live for oneself alone, but in the service of all mankind.
Everything that exists is in a manner the seed of that which will be.
Remember how often you have postponed minding your interest, and let slip opportunities.
Nothing is so bitter that a calm mind cannot find comfort in it.
He who is everywhere is nowhere.
In every action ask yourself: How does this relate to me? Will I regret it?
Do not waste the precious moments of this, your present life, brooding over the past or anticipating the future.
Not what we have but what we enjoy constitutes our abundance.
If you do not wish to be prone to anger, do not feed the habit; give it nothing which may tend to its increase.
Each day provides its own gifts.
Look well into thyself; there is a source of strength which will always spring up if thou wilt always look.
What springs from earth dissolves to earth again, and heaven-born things fly to their native seat.
Where a man's wound is, that is where his genius will be.
The present is all we possess. The past is gone and the future has not yet come.
A man's true delight is to do the things he was made for.
Let your every action, word, and thought be those of one who could depart from life at any moment.
No man is good by chance. Virtue has to be learnt.
Men do not care how nobly they live, but only how long, although it is within the reach of every man to live nobly, but within no man's power to live long.

october.quote: You could leave life right now. Let that determine what you do and say and think.
Think of yourself as dead. You have lived your life. Now take what's left and live it properly.
Let us prepare our minds as if we'd come to the very end of life. Let us postpone nothing. Let us balance life's books each day.
It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.
october.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 1.3

october.quote: You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire.
october.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 1.4

october.quote: Do not act as if you were going to live ten thousand years. Death hangs over you. While you live, while it is in your power, be good.

Pass through this brief patch of time in harmony with nature, and come to your final resting place gracefully, just as a ripened olive might drop, praising the earth that nourished it and grateful to the tree that gave it growth.
Soon you will have forgotten everything. Soon everybody will have forgotten you.
Think constantly how many physicians have died, after furrowing their brows over the sick; and how many astrologers after predicting with great pretensions the deaths of others.
Perfection of character is this: to live each day as if it were your last, without frenzy, without apathy, without pretense.
Everything lasts for a day, the one who remembers and the remembered.
All things are ephemeral, both the rememberer and the remembered.
Alexander the Great and his stable boy were both brought to the same place by death.

Keep before your eyes from day to day death and exile and everything that seems terrible, but most of all death; and then you will never have any abject thought nor will you yearn for anything beyond measure.
The longest-lived and the shortest-lived lose the same thing. The present is all that they can give up, since that is all you have, and what you do not have, you cannot lose.
When you kiss your child or your wife, say to yourself that you are kissing a mortal, and thus you will not be disturbed if either of them dies.
Life is very short and anxious for those who forget the past, neglect the present, and fear the future.
october.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 10.2

october.quote: Even while we speak, envious time has passed: pluck the day, trusting as little as possible in the next.
Before I became old I tried to live well; now that I am old, I shall try to die well; but dying well means dying gladly.
Let death and exile and every other thing which appears dreadful be daily before your eyes, but most of all death; and you will never think of anything mean nor will you crave anything excessively.
How many have been celebrated in fame and now are forgotten? How many who celebrated them have long since departed?
Do not despise death, but be content with it, since this too is one of those things which nature wills.
We are born for a brief span of life, to this man has been given as much as to him who has lived longest.
october.attribution: Seneca - On the Shortness of Life 8.1

october.quote: Look at all existing things: they are already in dissolution, and in change, and as it were in decay or dispersion.
Remember that man lives only in the present, in this fleeting instant; all the rest of his life is either past and gone, or not yet revealed.
The present is the only thing of which anyone can be deprived.
In the life of a man, his time is but a moment, his being an incessant flux, his sense a dim rushlight, his body a prey of worms, his soul an unquiet eddy.
Death smiles at us all; all we can do is smile back.
When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive—to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love.
Life is like a play: it is not the length but the excellence of the acting that matters.
Death is a release from the impressions of the senses, and from desires that make us their puppets, and from the vagaries of the mind, and from the hard service of the flesh.

november.quote: He who is not satisfied with a little, is satisfied with nothing.
november.attribution: Epicurus - as cited by Seneca in Moral Letters 2.6

november.quote: Do not seek to have events happen as you want them to, but instead want them to happen as they do happen, and your life will go well.
No person has the power to have everything they want, but it is in their power not to want what they don't have, and to cheerfully put to good use what they do have.
It is in no man's power to have whatever he wants; but he has it in his power not to wish for what he hasn't got, and cheerfully make the most of the things that do come his way.
That which Fortune has not given, she cannot take away.
Let us be grateful to people who make us happy; they are the charming gardeners who make our souls blossom.
It is more civilized to make fun of life than to bewail it.
Be content with what you are; the gods made you what you are for a reason.
The greatest blessings of mankind are within us and within our reach. A wise man is content with his lot, whatever it may be, without wishing for what he has not.
Count each day as a separate life.
A cucumber is bitter. Throw it away. There are briars in the road. Turn aside from them. This is enough. Do not add, 'And why were such things made in the world?'
He is a man of sense who does not grieve for what he has not, but rejoices in what he has.
No man is happy who does not think himself so.
Learn to be indifferent to what makes no difference.
How ridiculous not to flee from one's own wickedness, which is possible, yet endeavor to flee from another's wickedness, which is not possible.
The person who has enjoyed many blessings and is content with what has been granted to him does not grieve over what has passed.
If you live in harmony with nature you will never be poor; if you live according to opinion you will never be rich.
We do not cease to desire when we cease to hope.
For every minute you are angry you lose sixty seconds of happiness.
He who is contented is rich.
A rational person can find peace by cultivating indifference to things outside of their control.
Praise adds nothing to beauty.
Who is rich? He who is content. Who is that? Nobody.
In everything give thanks; this is the will of God concerning you.
True contentment depends not upon what we have; a tub was large enough for Diogenes, but a world was too little for Alexander.
The mind is its own place and can make a heaven of hell or a hell of heaven.
Remember that man's life lies all within this present, as it were but a hair's breadth of time.
He who lives in harmony with himself lives in harmony with the universe.
It is better, of course, to know useless things than to know nothing.
When you have eaten and are satisfied, then you shall bless.

december.quote: Let each thing you would do, say, or intend be like that of a dying person.
How small a part of the boundless and unfathomable time is assigned to every man! For it is very soon swallowed up in the eternal.
Life is neither good nor evil, but only a place for good and evil.
He who has lived in obscurity and peace cannot easily believe that there is any such thing as glory.
Look back over the past, empire succeeding empire—and from that, extrapolate the future: the same thing. No escape from the rhythm of events.
All things are changing: and thou thyself art in continuous mutation and in a manner in continuous destruction, and the whole universe too.
Withdraw into yourself. The rational principle which rules within, when it is in accordance with nature, so acts that it is content with itself.
What we do now echoes in eternity.
Consider how ephemeral and mean all mortal things are.
The mind is the ruler of the soul. It should remain unstirred by agitations of the flesh.
Erase the false impressions from your mind by constantly saying to yourself, I have it in my power to keep out evil.
The time of a man's life is as a point; the substance of it ever flowing, the sense obscure.
He has not learned the lesson of life who does not every day surmount a fear.
When your days are done and the end has come, what will they say of you?
A work well done is its own reward.
Men are disturbed by the view they take of things, not by things themselves.
What need is there to weep over parts of life? The whole of it calls for tears.
Even the longest life is but a glimpse. In the infinity of time, all men are equally forgotten.
Be not ashamed to be helped: thy business is to do thy duty like a soldier in the assault on a town.
Begin each day by reminding yourself: Today I shall meet with meddling, ungrateful, arrogant people.
Think on this doctrine, that reasoning beings were created for one another's sake.
Whatever the universal nature assigns to any man at any time is for the good of that man at that time.
All things from eternity are of like forms and come round in a circle.
Say to yourself first thing in the morning: today I shall meet with meddling, ungrateful, violent, treacherous, envious, and unsociable people.
How many after being celebrated in fame have been given up to oblivion; and how many who have celebrated the fame of others have long been dead.
